channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘A Quick Death or a Slow Death’: Prisoners Choose War to Get Lifesaving Drugs
item.description: An estimated 20 percent of Russia prisoner recruits are H.I.V. positive. To some, the front lines seemed less risky than prisons where they said they were denied effective treatments.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A captured Wagner fighter loyal to Russian forces being escorted by a Ukrainian guard at a prison in Dnipro, central Ukraine.

item.title: A Radical Experiment in Mental Health Care, Tested Over Centuries
item.description: In the Belgian town of Geel, families have long taken in people with psychiatric conditions. Could this approach work elsewhere?
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Koba Ryckewaert and Ilvy Njiokiktjien
item.media:description: Ann Peetermans and Iosif, who lives with her as a boarder, feeding a donkey in the backyard of her home in Geel, Belgium.

item.title: No Reprieve in Sudan Even for Eid Holiday as General Rejects Calls for Cease-Fire
item.description: Gunfights in the capital, Khartoum, continued for a seventh day, despite pleas for a pause as the Muslim-majority nation marked the end of the holy month of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Omer Erdem/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke rising in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, on Wednesday. International pressure has been mounting for a cease-fire to mark the Eid holidays.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Begin Training Ukraine on Abrams Tanks Within Weeks
item.description: The 31 M1 Abrams tanks promised by Washington could reach Ukraine by the fall, far sooner than expected, American officials say. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man on Thursday outside his garage, which was hit by shelling that left a huge crater in the backyard of his home in Kostiantynivka, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: As Gaza Celebrates Eid, a Gift for Women — and a Duty for Men
item.description: Palestinian Muslims give the eidiya — a gift of money — to female relatives and children on the Eid that marks the end of Ramadan. It is a revered tradition but one that can come with a heavy price.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stores in Gaza City offer special envelopes to put money in for gifts to women on Eid al-Fitr, marking the end of Ramadan.

item.title: Alejandro Toledo Returns to Peru Facing Charges in Corruption Case
item.description: Alejandro Toledo, who ruled Peru two decades ago, will be extradited from the United States. He has been charged in one of Latin America’s biggest corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: Bianca Padró Ocasio
item.media:description: The former Peruvian president Alejandro Toledo during a campaign rally in 2011 in Lima.

item.title: Canadian Suspect in Paris Synagogue Bombing Is Found Guilty
item.description: The attack killed four and injured dozens. But decades of false leads, a lack of evidence and legal wrangling delayed a trial.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A police officer at the scene of the attack in the Rue Copernic in Paris in October 1980. It was the first such attack on the French Jewish community since World War II.

item.title: Germany Names Panel to Investigate 1972 Munich Olympics Attack
item.description: The commission’s creation stems in part from an agreement made last year to reassess German failures in handling the attack by Palestinian militants, which killed 11 Israeli athletes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A member of the Black September Palestinian militant group during the standoff at the Olympic Village in Munich in 1972.

item.title: Dominic Raab, U.K. Deputy Prime Minister, Resigns Amid Bullying Scandal
item.description: The hard-line Brexiteer, one of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s most loyal political allies, was found by an independent inquiry to have mistreated subordinates.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Dominic Raab, leaving 10 Downing Street in London on Tuesday, said that the adverse findings against him were flawed.

item.title: ‘We Will Hunt You’: Ugandans Flee Ahead of Harsh Anti-Gay Law
item.description: The bill, passed last month, calls for life in prison for anyone engaging in same-sex relations. President Yoweri Museveni congratulated lawmakers for their “strong stand” against L.G.B.T.Q. people.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mbajjwe Nimiro Wilson, 24, a gay man from Uganda, in a safe house in Kenya.

item.title: Ukraine’s Social Media Stars Ditch Russian in Pivot to a War Footing
item.description: Russian was once the lingua franca of influencers in Ukraine. Now, not so much.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cafe and co-working space popular with influencers in Kyiv. Ukrainian social media figures are increasingly using Ukrainian instead of Russian for their online content.

item.title: What We Know About the Fighting in Sudan
item.description: The strategically important country in northeastern Africa has been consumed by days of fighting between two military factions, and plans for a transition to a civilian-led democracy are now in shambles.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke rose in Omdurman, Sudan, as fighting broke out on Saturday between two rival military factions in Khartoum, the capital, and around the country.

item.title: Sudan’s Generals Dined With Peace Negotiators, Then Started a War
item.description: What led the two generals, recently allies, to turn their forces on each other — devastating a country of 45 million people?
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Sudan’s army chief, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, in left photo, and Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, right, head of the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary unit, in 2019.

item.title: Why China’s Shrinking Population Is a Problem for Everyone
item.description: China struggled for years to curtail its rapid population growth. Now that its population is declining, economists and others fear serious implications for China and countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family cradling their child at a park in Beijing. China’s death rate surpassed its birth rate for the first time in decades this year.

item.title: Satellite Images of Sudan Show a Large Food Market Burned in Darfur
item.description: A Times analysis of satellite imagery shows how a displaced persons camp lost a key source of food and supplies amid a fight for control of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Pentagon Speeds Up Tank Timeline for Ukraine but Resists Calls for Jets
item.description: The U.S. will begin training Ukrainian troops on M1 Abrams tanks in the next few weeks, officials said, and combat-ready tanks could reach the battlefields by the fall.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army M1A1 Abrams tanks during NATO exercises in 2021 in Latvia.

item.title: Red Cross Expresses Alarm Over Detainee Health at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: As the prisoners age, their physical and mental health needs are increasingly challenging, the leader of a visiting delegation said.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A recovery room at the medical clinic in the Camp 5 detention center at Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: Canada Lands Volkswagen Battery Plant With Billions in Subsidies
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the assistance was needed to offset incentives offered by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a news conference on Friday on Volkswagen’s plan for a battery plant in Ontario.

item.title: For Earth Day, 7 Inspiring Reads
item.description: We picked some of our favorite articles from the Times’s Climate Desk.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times; Rachelle Baker; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Pentagon Aid Package to Ukraine Includes Old M21 Anti-Tank Mines
item.description: The M21 mines do not run afoul of international treaties. But unlike other mines the United States has given to Kyiv, they can be lethal indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A new weapons package for Ukraine from the Pentagon includes M21 anti-tank land mines.

item.title: Books You Can Read to Understand What’s Going on in Sudan
item.description: For a deeper understanding of what’s going on, here’s what to read.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke billowing this week over Sudan’s capital, Khartoum.

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Are Struggling to Deliver Key Weapons
item.description: Documents that were among leaked classified military assessments of the war reveal the struggles of Western allies to fulfill their pledged deliveries of tanks and other weapons systems.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Bahkmut in March. The United States’ delivery of 31 Abrams tanks to Ukraine is unlikely to be in place at the start of the counteroffensive against Russia.

item.title: Using A.I. in Everyday Life
item.description: People are already adopting the technology.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Open AI offices in San Francisco.

item.title: Russia Accidentally Bombs Belgorod, Its Own City, Injuring 3
item.description: A blast in Belgorod, near the Ukrainian border, was the result of “an accidental discharge of aviation ammunition,” Russia’s Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: A handout image shows the accident scene following a large blast in the city of Belgorod on Thursday.

item.title: The Biggest, Darkest Sky in Australia
item.description: Looking for darkness in Australia’s biggest state.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Giacomo d'Orlando for The New York Times
item.media:description: A starry night over the outback nearby Boodarie, Western Australia, in January.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The U.S. prepares for a possible evacuation of its embassy in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Smoke rose from Khartoum International Airport yesterday.

item.title: $14.8 Million in Gold and Valuables Vanishes From Toronto’s Airport
item.description: The police appear to know little about how the crime was committed or who is behind the theft.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Rick Madonik/Toronto Star via Getty Images
item.media:description: “Our goal is to solve this theft,” Inspector Stephen Duivesteyn said on Thursday. “For the public worried about flying out, there should be no concern.”

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Xi Rebuffs the U.S.
item.description: Also, a small town in Australia hosted tens of thousands of eclipse watchers.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil last week in Beijing.

item.title: Ukraine Grain Deal Raises Tensions for European Farmers
item.description: When Russia’s war blocked vitally needed grains at Ukrainian ports, officials succeeded in finding other routes out. But the solution brought its own problems.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grain vessel bound for Ethiopia at a port in Ukraine last year.

item.title: Search Halted for 3 Americans Missing Off the Mexican Coast
item.description: Kerry O’Brien, Frank O’Brien and William Gross, who were sailing aboard the Ocean Bound, were last heard from near Mazatlán, Mexico, on April 4.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: U.S. Coast Guard, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The search for the passengers of the Ocean Bound encompassed “an area larger than the state of California,” the Coast Guard said.

item.title: 1973: Moscow Walkout by Chinese Envoy
item.description: The official, Ma Lieh, left his seat during a speech at the Kremlin by a Soviet Politburo member, a sign of the strained relations between Moscow and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: British Man Died of Rare Blood Syndrome Linked to AstraZeneca’s Vaccine
item.description: One expert said the blood-clotting syndrome was estimated to occur in one in 50,000 people under 40 and one in 100,000 over 40 who received AstraZeneca’s vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Britain withdrew AstraZeneca’s vaccine for people under 30 in April 2021, citing the risk of rare blood clots.

item.title: Italy’s Senate Signs Off on Meloni’s Migrant Crackdown
item.description: The package is the first major take on immigration by the hard-right government of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and would limit integration and create more detention facilities.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants arriving in the port of Catania, Italy, this month.

item.title: NOAA Forecasters See a Respite for California
item.description: Less extreme spring temperatures could mean gradual snowmelt and lower flood risks, according to experts. “The picture is relatively optimistic,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a snowstorm in Running Springs, Calif., in March.

item.title: Israel’s Right-Wing Government Has Jewish Democrats at a Loss
item.description: American lawmakers defending Israel have often fallen back on what they call the countries’ shared democratic values. But defending the current far-right government is proving a lot harder.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis protesting against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s plan to overhaul the country’s judiciary, which has also divided American Jews.

item.title: U.S. Positioning Troops for Evacuation of American Embassy in Sudan
item.description: Fierce fighting has trapped people in the capital, Khartoum, and the United States says it is “conducting prudent planning” to get diplomatic staff members out.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Elian Peltier and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Smoke billowing on Thursday above the airport in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum.

item.title: Stampede in Yemen Kills 78 People Gathering to Receive Holiday Donations
item.description: A crowd had gathered to collect handouts of a small sum of money ahead of the Eid al-Fitr holiday that marks the end of the holy fasting month of Ramadan for Muslims.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Gathering near the site of a stampede in the Yemeni capital, Sana, on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon’s Repatriation of Algerian Leaves 30 Prisoners at Guantánamo
item.description: The transfer was the sixth of a cleared prisoner in six months in a Biden administration surge to reduce the prison population.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: Bakush, Said bin Brahim bin Umran
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A prisoner at Guantánamo Bay’s detention center in 2019.

item.title: Fighting Intensifies in Khartoum as Sudan Cease-Fires Fail
item.description: With two generals vying for power, residents in the Sudanese capital said the violence had destroyed hospitals, airfields and homes, and left civilians caught in the crossfire.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Fleeing residential neighborhoods in Khartoum, Sudan, on Wednesday.

item.title: NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg Says Ukraine’s ‘Rightful Place’ Is in the Alliance
item.description: “I am here today with a simple message: NATO stands with Ukraine,” Jens Stoltenberg, the alliance’s secretary general, said at a joint news conference with the Ukrainian president.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston
item.media:description: NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, center, visiting a remembrance wall in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Thousands Flock to See a Rare Total Solar Eclipse in Australia
item.description: Tens of thousands descended on a tiny town in Western Australia, hundreds of miles from any city, to view a celestial spectacle.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching a total solar eclipse in Exmouth, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: Democrats’ Numbers Problem
item.description: We look at the costs of Dianne Feinstein’s absence to the Democratic Party’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Dianne Feinstein last year.

item.title: As Xi Befriends World Leaders, He Hardens His Stance on the U.S.
item.description: China has rebuffed calls to restart high-level talks with the United States, raising the risk of confrontation in contested areas like the Taiwan Strait.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil last week in Beijing.

item.title: Biden Pledges $500 Million to Stop Deforestation in Brazil
item.description: The promise to help Brazil protect the Amazon must be approved by Congress, where Republicans are opposed to foreign climate aid.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Logging in the Caxiuanã National Forest, located in the lower Amazon region of Brazil’s state of Pará.

item.title: Yellen Calls for ‘Constructive’ China Relationship
item.description: The Treasury secretary laid out a vision in which the United States could continue cooperating economically with China despite what she described as acute security threats.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Janet L. Yellen, the Treasury secretary, said that the actions the United States had taken against China were aimed at protecting national security, not gaining economic advantage.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: India will soon have the world’s largest population.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Stampede in Yemen’s Capital Kills Dozens Seeking Food Aid, Houthis Say
item.description: Hundreds of people had gathered at a school for an event organized by merchants, according to the Houthi-run Interior Ministry.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Armed Houthi fighters in Sana, Yemen, in 2021. A stampede in Sana led to nearly 80 deaths, according to the Houthis, who run the city.

item.title: Inspector General Says U.S. Aid May Be Flowing to the Taliban
item.description: The special inspector general for Afghanistan’s reconstruction accused the Biden administration of blocking his efforts to track assistance.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: John Sopko, the special inspector general for Afghan reconstruction, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Uneven Cease-Fire in Sudan Makes Escape Hard for Desperate Civilians
item.description: The army and the paramilitary group it is battling agreed to a 24-hour cease-fire. But many residents were unsure whether the truce was solid enough to safely flee.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: People trying to flee Khartoum, Sudan, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Swift NATO Membership for Sweden
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, visiting Sweden, said he hoped that objections to adding the country to the alliance would be ironed out by midsummer, when member states meet in Lithuania.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III and his Swedish counterpart, Pal Jonson, at Musko Naval Base on Wednesday.

item.title: A Pink Door Is Deemed Too Bright for Edinburgh
item.description: Miranda Dickson was told that the color failed “to preserve the character” of the Scottish city’s New Town district, a UNESCO World Heritage site. This week she painted the door peacock green.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Miranda Dickson was ordered to repaint the pink door of her three-story Georgian townhouse in Edinburgh’s New Town district. “The whole thing is just completely bonkers,” she said.

item.title: Mystery Light Over Kyiv Prompts Sirens and Speculation
item.description: Theories ran rampant among the public and officials after the Ukrainian capital was illuminated Wednesday night, but government agencies pointed to a satellite on re-entry or a meteor.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Authorizes a New Round of Covid Boosters
item.description: Older Americans and those with weakened immune systems, groups still particularly vulnerable to the virus, may receive additional shots of the reformulated vaccine, federal officials said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The C.D.C. said only about 43 percent of adults 65 and older had received their first booster shot.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: India’s Population Milestone
item.description: Also, China’s nuclear buildup.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A train station in Mumbai, India.

item.title: In Prosecution of Turkey’s Halkbank, Supreme Court Issues a Mixed Ruling
item.description: The justices rejected key arguments from Halkbank, which is owned by the Turkish government. But they told a lower court to revisit one possible defense.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: A branch of Halkbank in Istanbul. The Supreme Court rejected the Turkish bank’s main argument but sent another defense back to a lower court.

item.title: How Russian Propaganda Plagues Parts of Eastern Ukraine
item.description: A year into the war, some residents of eastern Ukrainian towns still confound officials and the police with their support for Russia despite the constant bombardment from Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko, Dyma Shapoval and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Natasha, right, standing with a neighbor outside of her home, the site of a Russian strike, last month in Kostyantynivka, Ukraine.

item.title: Bear That Killed Jogger in Italy Is Captured
item.description: The governor of a province in a mountainous region of the country’s north sought to euthanize the bear, known as JJ4, but a court is reviewing the matter.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The local forest service found the bear, JJ4, this week and took her to a wildlife center.

item.title: Austin Defends Giving Young Service Members Access to Classified Data
item.description: After a 21-year-old Air National Guardsman was accused of leaking top secret documents, Mr. Austin said the real issue was ensuring that all service members protect information.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III during a news conference Wednesday in Sweden.
